nodes.text: Lexicon-based sentiment analysis using Hedonometer may differ from machine-learning based sentiment analysis (Microsoft Azure) because some Hedonometer lexical entries could systematically cause score differences across domains
We compare Hedonometer (lexicon-based) sentiment scores to Microsoft Azure Text Analytics (machine-learning based) across four English-language domains to identify lexical entries driving differences
Data comprised ~150,000 texts from four domains: Finance (~5,000 phrases), News (~50,000 articles), Social media (40,000 tweets), and IMDb reviews (50,000 reviews)

Model differences between Hedonometer and Azure sentiment scores per document using linear regression with Hedonometer lexical entries as independent variables and examine variable p-values to identify influential words
Hedonometer lexicon contains 10,222 words; the datasets contained subsets: Finance 966 words, News 274, Social media 1,886, IMDB 2,673 and 3,810 distinct Hedonometer words across all domains
Azure produces sentiment scores in range 0 (negative) to 1 (positive); Hedonometer produces averaged 'happiness' scores with a relatively smaller range for some domains
We restricted analysis to Hedonometer words that appear in at least three of the four domains to find words consistently acting as outliers

Figure 1 shows domain differences: Finance and News mostly agree between Hedonometer and Azure with few extreme differences; Social media shows greater differences; IMDB shows extreme differences and poor agreement

Linear regression p-values identify words with smallest p-values (words that would need weight changes to match Azure) and largest p-values (words interpreted similarly by both methods); Table III lists domain-specific words
There are domain-dependent differences in which words are important for mapping Hedonometer to Azure, i.e., word importance depends on domain rather than there being universal outlier words
No major single outlier Hedonometer word systematically causes differences across domains; only 'mom' appears with extreme p-values in more than one domain
Spearman correlations between Hedonometer ranking and p-value ranking are small: Finance -0.1126, News -0.1206, Social media 0.2949, IMDB 0.3300, indicating little consistent relation
Because only 3,810 of 10,222 Hedonometer words appeared in the texts, limited lexicon coverage may constrain findings but does not invalidate identification of domain-specific influential words

Adjusting individual Hedonometer word weights would likely have limited effect on overall sentiment scores and may not be worthwhile if tools are used consistently and comparisons remain like-with-like

Future work: target texts containing specific Hedonometer words to increase coverage and consider non-parametric models or multiple hypothesis correction to address many-feature regression and feature importance
